author: {'steamid': '76561198026123571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1532818107}
review:
Simply having an original take on a metroidvania concept is not enough these days.

Now, blending smooth tunes with scrumptious colorful visuals is already a good start. But add to that clever little pinball puzzles, an overworld of interconnected pathways and curious setpieces, and YIE is elevated to a game any platform would be proud to have.

Personal standouts: 
The story vignettes with the cute and colorful characters have a good balance of bitter and sweet elements and restrained sense of humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993580304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1396, 'last_played': 1635021170}
review: Loved the demo, bought the game. Relaxing casual adventure with pinball mashed in - if you liked Peggle you'll probably like this. Exploration with great atmosphere, graphics, music & sound, mix of skill and luck and engaging enough for me to 100% it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139158591', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1533451076}
review:
I recently finished Yoku’s Island Express. It’s a wonderful game, and my early pick for metroidvania of the year. The presentation is right up there with Hollow Knight and Ori and the Blind Forest, the pinball gameplay is fresh, and the story is adorable with interesting characters.

Being a metroidvania, you’ve got a variety of power-ups, a map, backtracking, fast travel, bosses, regular and “true” endings, collectibles and secrets.

Unlike other games in its genre, there’s no jumping, dashing or wall-climbing, which are all replaced by various pinball flippers and bumpers. It’s also a mostly conflict-free game, with traditional boss fights being replaced by pinball challenges. 

There’s only one game mode and difficulty level in Yoku’s Island Express. If Hollow Knight were a 10 on the difficulty scale, Yoku would be a 5, with most of the challenge coming from precise pinballing. There’s also no dying in this game. The greatest punishment, except for losing currency, is when you accidentally fling yourself off a ledge and have to backtrack back.

It took me about 8.5hrs to beat the main story, and 13hrs to reach 97% completion, so there’s plenty of game here. 

Yoku’s Island Express is a game full of color, cheer and charm, oozing a style more commonly associated with Nintendo. If you’re looking for a modern metroidvania, Yoku won’t disappoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966435383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1532725136}
review:
(I can only choose Recommended or Not Recommended, but this is more Barely Not Recommended Because It's Not For Me.)

A super highly polished, laid back pinball-Metroidvania with beautiful art. Visually, it's like Ori and the Blind Forest meets the modern Donkey Kong Country games. It's extremely well made for what it is, but it wasn't what I was expecting. 

If you watch the trailers, you can see that there are two main types of flippers: regular pinball flippers, and flat flippers that push you upwards/forwards like the springs in the Sonic games. These flat flippers are the main way you move around (other than walking) for 80% of the game, and unlike Sonic springs they always push you in a predetermined direction regardless of your momentum. For example, if you are rolling to the right at maximum speed and you launch yourself with an upwards-facing flipper, you'll instantly lose all of your horizontal momentum and jump straight upwards. They're like the barrels in Donkey Kong Country or the automatic/setpiece springs in 3D Sonic games, if you've played either of those.

Also, you need to grind for money. A lot. There were several points in the game where I couldn't continue to the next section until I had enough cash to unlock a flipper, but the only way I could get enough cash was to spend several minutes backtracking until I found a pinball table where I could spend several more minutes slowly earning enough money. The game is super non-linear so I can't guarantee that everyone will have to grind as much as I did, but I get the feeling that most people will end up in a similar situation at least once or twice.

The reason I say "several minutes backtracking" is that backtracking is slower than any other Metroidvania I have played. You unlock movement options throughout the game, but unless I somehow missed an important ability in my playthrough, all of them only work in very specific places (e.g. from the trailer: you can only swing when there's a grapple point and you can only swim when there's water). So even if you're a super skilled player with all your end-game abilities unlocked, backtracking through an early section will be no faster than it was when you started. Thankfully there are certain 'train stations' you can fast-travel between, which helps a lot, but backtracking to places away from the 'train lines' is still painfully time-consuming. And if the reason you're backtracking is that you need to grind a large amount of money to unlock one of the train lines in the first place, as I did, then it's not particularly useful.

Overall, I was expecting a physics-based game about skillfully moving a pinball around a Metroid-style connected world, to scratch the same itch as something like Super Monkey Ball, 2D Sonic or a grappling hook game. Instead, I got a game that is 80% slowly walking from place to place, talking to characters, backtracking for collectibles and grinding for money, and 20% pinball tables. And a tiny bit of swinging from grapple points, but then my percentages don't add up nicely. If you want to play a beautiful slow-paced relaxing collectathon with some pinball sections, I highly recommend it! It's just not what I was looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021306083', 'num_games_owned': 848, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1532364527}
review:
Genre mashups are a tricky thing. When they work, they can be some of the most memorable games ever made, taking players by surprise and making you wonder why no-one thought of doing it before. Portal is a good example, melding first-person shooting with puzzles in a way that few had seen before. Even though Portal 2 is generally considered the better game, many people—myself included—name the original as their favorite due to the magic that comes with a new experience. Mashups don’t always work out this well. Darksiders combines Zelda-style dungeons with God of War combat and even imitates Portal at one stage. While Darksiders is a good game, it feels like a tribute to the games it takes inspiration from, rather than being its own thing.

I’m pleased to say that Yoku’s Island Express falls into Portal‘s category. Its genre mash-up of metroidvania and pinball is something I didn’t realize I needed in my life until now. It’s been 25 years since I got hooked on Sonic Spinball, but Yoku’s Island Express brought back all that joy and more. (Sonic Spinball has a bit of dubious reputation, so to be clear, I mean this as a compliment).

In Yoku’s Island Express, you play as the titular beetle Yoku on his first day as postmaster on Mokumana Island. The island’s deity is trapped in an endless sleep and it’s Yoku’s job to deliver letters requesting help from the island’s leaders. It’s a thin excuse to have you explore the island but it works for me. The characters are charming and the writing is short and to the point. Less can definitely be more, and I ended up surprisingly attached to the characters and the island’s history. Developer Villa Gorilla tells a decent story and doesn’t let it get in the way of the fun.

Given the unusual concept, it’s surprising how quickly the controls become intuitive. You can only move Yoku left and right and you can’t jump at all. Movement around the stages is done by using flippers and bumpers which you operate much like you would those on a pinball table. There were a few minutes at the start where the lack of mid-air control felt a touch weird, however bouncing Yoku around with the flippers soon became second nature.

Mokumana island is one connected world, however there are distinct stages covering the usual weather-based themes of forest, snow, water, and desert. Each area feels like a separate pinball table and, in turn, each table is broken up into small sections with light puzzles to solve before moving on.

The stages all look stunning. There are a surprising amount of art layers in both the foreground and the background, many of them moving independently, giving a sense of scale to the world not often found in 2D side-scrollers. There’s also a watercolor effect to much of the art which makes it look like a painting when there are no flippers or collectibles on screen.

The characters are immediately charming, looking like they’ve come straight out of a children’s picture book. Games often make an immediate visual impression which then fades as you start to take it for granted. With Yoku’s Island Express, it was almost the opposite. I appreciated the visuals more at the end than at the beginning. It’s a feast for the eyes that improves upon closer inspection.

The visuals complement the gameplay perfectly. Pinball is usually a stressful game. You’re constantly reacting with a split-second’s notice as you desperately try to maintain combos and rack up high scores. Yoku’s Island Express isn’t your typical pinball game and it ends up being a really chill experience. My initial six-hour playthrough was relaxing and rarely frustrating. Most of the puzzles are fairly obvious and you don’t need to be a skilled pinball player to get through the story. There’s a decent amount of leeway with the physics. If you want Yoku and his dung ball to shoot up a tube, you just need to make contact with the entrance and the game will do the rest.

Yoku’s Island Express has a few boss battles scattered around although I found these rather disappointing. Villa Gorilla didn’t seem to know how to incorporate bosses into the pinball structure. Each boss requires you to perform specific actions on the table but given the hectic nature of pinball, you can accomplish this without ever really understanding it. I found myself doing damage and triggering new phases in boss encounters without knowing what I’d done. They’re also rather easy. The lack of any punishment for death means that you don’t have to pay attention to the boss itself. One boss took me a while to beat, but that was only because I had a tendency to regularly drop down to a lower level as I tried to pull off the exact move required.

The levels (or “tables,” if you prefer) are constructed in such a way that it’s rare to lose progress by falling back to the bottom. This did happen to me once but getting back wasn’t too painful. You’re constantly unlocking shortcuts and, once you’ve cleared a path, retracing your steps is relatively straightforward.

It’s worth revisiting the earlier locations anyway because Yoku regularly acquires new abilities such as swimming underwater and swinging from plants to make previously unreachable areas accessible. Yoku can also complete side quests for island residents and there are thirty collectible Wickerlings that’ll you need for a secret ending. You should also keep an eye out for treasure chests which contain loads of the fruit-based currency you use to buy upgrades. I completed Yoku’s Island Express in six hours, however there’s plenty more to do after beating the story. I haven’t reached 100% yet, but it’s likely to take around ten hours, possibly more.

Yoku’s quest takes him all over the island, although navigation can be a touch confusing at times. Early on, you’re given three letters to deliver to people at extreme ends of the island. It looks like you can complete these deliveries in any order, however there’s actually a fixed order which you might not realize until you’ve banged your head against a wall for fifteen minutes.

Quest design could have been improved slightly all round. There were a few times when I was given what I thought was an optional side quest only to find out it was a mandatory part of the main mission. After a conversation with an NPC, I wasted ten minutes looking for the way forward because I hadn’t noticed there was someone off-screen I needed to talk to before progressing. These are all minor issues and didn’t impact my experience much.

Once you’ve opened up the map, you can use the beehive travel system to get from one end to the other. This helps cut out some backtracking and is especially useful for collectible hunting. The beehive system doesn’t take you everywhere, though, and there are only a handful of locations where you can jump on.

Yoku’s Island Express is a beautiful combination of pinball and metroidvania. It doesn’t require you to be particularly skilled at either and lacks the challenge often associated with both of those genres. However, I thoroughly enjoyed bouncing Yoku and his dungball around Mokumana Island and the collectibles are rewarding enough to have me working towards 100% completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988258200', 'num_games_owned': 458, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1532710742}
review:
Сначала хотел написать положительный отзыв так как игра очень понравилась. Аркада и пинбол хоть и не самые мои любимые жанры но очень даже ничего. Но пройдя чуть больше половины и дойдя до места где нужно разобраться почему сбоит двигатель космического корабля у меня как это сейчас говорится пригорело. Может это и нормально считается для аркады, но я готов был геймпад разбить. До миллиметра нужно попадать в трубу, а потом при попадаании по пауку тебя с большим шансом скидывает обратно и ты опять полчасапытаешься попасть в эту долбаную трубу.
В общем нервы дороже.
Пожалуйста, проектируйте уровни не только на профи игроков.

Дополню свой обзор и переверну палец вверх. Через пару дней после написания вышеизложенного текста вышел патч и я попробовал пройти паука снова. Он доставил мне гораздо меньше хлопот чем ранее. Не могу с уверенностью сказать что это решилось патчем или я просто наловчился, но в итоге сюжет игры я прошёл. 
Игра понравилась. Остались ещё непройденные моменты, собрать все корешки, разнести всю почту и прочее, но это я уже ленюсь делать как и во многих других играх после прохождения сюжетки.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055780740', 'num_games_owned': 5600, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1532374143}
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7871885/]Follow our curator page:[b] OCG-Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[u]Rating[/u]
[b]8.5/10[/b] 

[u]Pros:[/u]  
Metroidvania-style upgrades are meaningful
The Pinball Aspect blends well with the Metroidvania
Lovable Characters
Awe-inspiring Graphics
Interesting Story
Real Open World Gameplay

[u]Cons:[/u] 
Occasional Performance Stutters
Short Main Story Length

[h1]Overview[/h1] 
“Yoku’s Island Express is a metroidvania crossed with a pinball game. While this is an odd combination, it works quite well and provides an exhilarating adventure through a diverse landscape. It is so good it is hard to put the game down. The graphics are amazing and make the environment feel alive. The sound is great, for the most part, but some character voices can be grating. Overall this is a great title full of non-stop action that does have a short run time if you are only in it for the main story. 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]

[u]Gameplay:[/u] 
 
Pinball
The core concept behind the pinball gameplay is pretty simple, hit the ball that our protagonist Yoko is attached to into the appropriate objects to get to the next pinball stage. To do this, each stage has paddles that are colored either blue or orange. Pushing L2 on a controller makes the blue paddles raise, and pushing R2 will make the orange paddles raise. Some paddles are both blue and orange which means either button will push these, they are mainly for puzzles though, which are often the objective of the stage. The objective can come in a variety of versions. The main one that a player will see the most is the purple keys puzzle. Objects that shine with purple particles are scattered throughout a pinball stage. These can range anywhere from spinner signs, to frozen sphere that must be broken by hitting them, to hitting the ball into a certain area multiple times. Once these objectives are accomplished, purple key fragments will fly to predetermined positions on the screen. Once these fragments are collected, then a door will open to the next stage and the player can progress. The pinball mechanics in this game are very similar to a typical pinball table in that they have simulated physics and an overarching goal. Unlike normal pinball however, the goal is not to score the most points but is to instead advance to the next level and continue the player’s quest. 

Metroidvania-style Upgrades
To get further in this quest, the player will have to gain new powers. This is gained in the stereotypical metroidvania style. New obstacles are introduced and a short puzzle must be completed to gain these powers. The powers can later be upgraded to be more effective. “Yoku’s Island Express” does this quite seamlessly. After completing a few stages of pinball, the player will gain access to either the item itself or they will gain the knowledge of where the item is located. If the item is located in an already explored area, this title is quite generous with its shortcuts and will let the player skip entire pinball stage sequences. These shortcuts can be either be free, or they can be bought with the world’s currency, fruit. Fruit is thankfully quite easy to come by and can be easily farmed while playing pinball stages. This is why the fruit wallet upgrade is so important. New items will also be used when facing off against the bosses in the game. 

Bosses
The bosses in this title are a bit limited due to the pinball gameplay, but that didn’t hinder my fun with these sequences. Bosses are one of the few times the palyer has to contend with multiball. Not only will multiball be included most times, but these extra pinballs must be used to solve puzzles too. This creates tension and hectic gameplay as the player is forced to solve a puzzle while simultaneously trying to hit all of the pinballs into their appropriate positions. Bosses are meaningful to the story though, which gives the battles meaning and makes them more interesting. Two mechanics that were given more story than they usually have are side quests and collectibles. 

Side Quests and Collectibles
What pleased me with “Yoku’s Island Express” is that every side quest has a well fleshed out story that often somehow pertains to the overarching story, though it isn’t necessary to complete it. These side quests are often worthwhile too, because they can provide amazing upgrades such as fruit, the game’s currency, storage upgrades and metroidvania item upgrades that make them more effective and easy to use. What surprised me the most is that the game’s collectibles also have their own story attached to them. I usually despise collectibles because they are meant to elongate a game and usually have no purpose other than to unlock concept art or music. The collectibles in this title though power an entity that ties right into the story, and actually unlocks the true ending.

[b]Overall:[/b] 
This is a unique game that is worth a look if a player is looking for something that hasn’t been done before. “Yoku’s Island Express” executes all of its mechanics well and it is worthwhile for anyone that enjoys the metroidvania genre. 


[u]Story:[/u] 
The story is a bit of an odd one. The player controls Yoku, the friendly beetle who has become the new postman for a small island. Yoku quickly finds himself at the forefront of an operation to save the island’s protective god, using all of the ball rolling skills that he has brought with him. Something I never understood story-wise is where all of the pinball platforms came from. I understand that this is more of a gameplay over story moment, but it is a bit of a plot hole which perturbed me. 

[u]Sound:[/u] 
The sound in this game is quite satisfying. The music is subtle and doesn’t overpower the entire game, as this title want’s the player to focus on the art, world, and gameplay. The sound design works well, but the “Animal Crossing” style of sound-based voice acting can get tiring. Especially since some voices aren’t pleasant to listen to and a new clip plays with each piece of dialogue. The player’s character however is quite lively and doesn’t speak at all. He does however react to what is currently occurring gameplay-wise. This means that if the player accidentally throws their ball down the side of a mountain, Yoku will start shrieking in fear. 

 [u]Graphics:[/u] 
The graphics in this game is its second best feature, besides the gameplay. The characters are so well drawn and animated in the cartoonish artstyle that I was excited to see what kind of creature would pop-up next. While most of the creatures in the world are cartoon versions of animals that exist in the real world, some happen to be mythical creatures that are both intriguing and disturbing simultaneously. The animations feel so fluid and really help make the world feel like it is living and breathing. The environments are designed in such a way to be easily recognizable also. This is important because many of the side quests require back tracking, so it is important to know where the player is immediately. 

[u]Performance:[/u] 
The performance in this game is fine for the most part. When a new area is being loaded it seems like the game stutters while it loads this area. This can be frustrating, but it doesn’t affect gameplay in any meaningful way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137317660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2, 'last_played': 1532257460}
review:
Da es sich in kein mir bekanntes Genre drücken lässt, würde ich es am ehesten als "Action Pinball Adventure Plattformer" bezeichnen. Investiert habe ich in das Spiel ( offline ) etwa 10h und die waren gut angelegt. Belohnt wurde ich mit einer farbenfrohen und liebevoll gestalteten Welt voller Überraschungen und einzigartigen Spielmechaniken. Teilweise knifflig, war das Spiel zu keiner Zeit "nicht schaffbar" und niemals langweilig.
Die Story ist gelungen, kinderfreundlich und birgt einige unvorhergesehene Twists, die lediglich in kleinen Dialogen angedeutet werden.

Von mir bekommt das Spiel 10/10 Mistbällen

review: I love this game!!!! its hours and hours of fun for you or the whole family! My only concern is that after I played the first hour I got a script error and the game locked up. but when I went back to my desktop and started the game again 3 hours and no problems!!! thinking maybe the next update for it might help but all in all I love this game! author: {'steamid': '76561197967571077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1531005293}
review:
This is a charming little game that can only be described as a “platforming pinball adventure game.” Words I've never believed would ever be uttered in a single sentence before. If that doesn't get you at least mildly curious about this game, nothing will. It is not hard (indeed there is no way to die) and it is short enough to not wear out its welcome, yet for all its minor annoyances and flaws… it is a charming, colorful, and innovative game.

Ultimately, I don't think its a great game (just a good one), but being the only “platforming pinball adventure game” I know of, it deserves a recommendation in my book just for being so unique.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046433087', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1531815201}
review:
[h1]Игра, которой мы вообще не заслужили.[/h1]

Забудьте о ее существовании. Вы ведь ждали Второго Пришествия Иисуса? Вот оно. Проходил с закрытыми глазами, лишь бы не ослепнуть от божественного света, исходящего из монитора.
 
Нравится вам пинбол или нет -- вы просто обязаны в это поиграть! Villa Gorilla проделали колоссальную работу: собрали сногсшибательный микс из [b]умопомрачительного визуала[/b], прекрасного, ненавязчивого [b]саундтрека[/b], гармонично подчеркивающего настроение каждой локации, [b]ярких персонажей[/b], которые заставят вас улыбаться, словно вы умственноотсталый, и [b]тщательно проработанного левелдизайна[/b] с тонной секретов, от которого порой голова кругом. Если бы я назвал это идеальным тортом из лучших ингридиентов, то соврал бы. Ведь если вы сожрете огромный, хоть и вкусный торт в одну, извиняюсь, харю, то через час уже будете валяться в диабетической коме, а о тортах до конца жизни не захотите думать. Yoku's Island Express -- это маленький кусочек вкуснейшего торта в мире: вы его уплели за обе щеки, но вам хочется еще, у вас наворачиваются слезы от вожделения, в голове гудит, руки трясутся, вы нервно ерзаете на стуле и пытаетесь сфокусировать взгляд в одной точке, лишь бы не потерять сознание... Но с другой стороны вы понимаете, что еще от одного куска вас с хлопком разнесет. Поэтому вы просто отставляете тарелку и уже начинаете мечтать о том дне, когда снова получится вкусить этой манны небесной. 

[i]Смело заношу Йоку в личный топ "игр всех времен и народов" и вам советую.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198445880085', 'num_games_owned': 2749, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 6325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1808, 'last_played': 1693671758}
review: 弹球+解谜，挺新鲜而奇妙的组合。美术风格清新明快，音乐也让人心情放松，单论这两点已经值回票价了。[spoiler] 或者说其实是因为这两个理由入的游戏？[/spoiler]这款游戏属于那种即使进度100%通关了，但之后隔了很久再玩，依旧会给自己带来惊喜的作品，伴随着轻松欢快的音乐，操纵着Yoku在Mokumana岛任意漫步的感觉，真的十分惬意。总之，我还是会为这款游戏点起我的拇指，希望能在以后见到更多具有可玩性的内容。[spoiler] 虽然感觉并不实际[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198003352401', 'num_games_owned': 1224, 'num_reviews': 384, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1615674515}
review:
J’ai beau être fan de flipper, j’avais vraiment peur que les déplacements sur l’île soient très rapidement pénibles.

Au lieu de ça, non seulement j’ai pris énormément de plaisir à découvrir Makumana grâce à un level design aux petits oignons, mais en plus le jeu dans sa globalité rend heureux.

J’ai passé 5h avec un sourire béat, à profiter de la beauté des paysages et de la bande-son.

Les zones traversées sont variées, les tables sans cesse renouvelées et les développeurs ont réussi à ajouter de nombreuses mécaniques pour diversifier au maximum la progression du joueur.

Si on ajoute à ça les secrets et quêtes annexes pour continuer de jouer une fois l’aventure principale terminée, c’est du tout bon. Les Suédois de Villa Gorilla frappent un grand coup avec un premier jeu novateur.

Franchement, qui aurait osé mixer flipper et exploration ? Ne passez pas à côté cette année !

[url=https://www.gamesidestory.com/2018/07/13/yokus-island-express/]Lire le test complet sur Game Side Story[/url]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CgqDPeWqoXs

author: {'steamid': '76561197989807190', 'num_games_owned': 2276, 'num_reviews': 599, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1531431176}
review:
I like metroidvania/exploration-focused games, but it's hard to deny that a lot of them try to follow the best examples (like Super Metroid or Symphony of the Night) a bit too closely and, as a result, feeling a bit disappointing. No matter how amazing they are, there might be a sense of familiarity to the point of games becoming predictable. So when a game like Knytt Underground, Treasure Adventure World, Toki Tori 2 or this title, Yoku’s Island Express, appear, it's always refreshing and exciting to check them out. Even if they might turn out not as amazing as you hope.

The main "gimmick" for Yoku’s Island Express is pinball. You heard that right, not just ball physics like Knytt Underground, but actual pinball tables built into levels with two trigger buttons representing the flippers at all points of the game. And it's quite surprising how well it often works together. While there is, of course, barely any sense of "challenge" and a lot of "difficulty" rather comes from luck, while mistakes lead to time waste, which isn't good, more often than not, it's actually pretty fun to figure out ways to progress while thinking about the character (or, technically, the ball they are carrying) as a pinball ball. It's not the only way of traversal, since you can walk and later get few more abilities, but they are far less interesting compared to this weird mix of platforming exploration and pinball.

Sadly, the time waste and luck factor become rather frustrating as game goes on, even if you are not playing this exploration focused game for exploration. The two biggest offenders are the boss battles (which just take way too much time and lucky precision), except for the actually fun final boss fight, and the swinging mechanics. I've seen some weird swinging mechanics in my time, but this one is the worst, as both visual and sound based details about it aren't cues, but rather make it harder to aim each swing. If you had issues with Bionic Commando, you will hate it here, though, luckily, these are required only in few areas.

It's somewhat easy to excuse those, eventually, given the novelty of the game idea and actually well designed levels. And for the cute visual style and music as well, along with all the little NPC stories you can follow on the island. Backtracking in some areas can be annoying, but at the same time, it is possible to grab most of the things on the first go to each area and you can continue the game even after the final boss fight to finish all the unfinished "quests".

What is somewhat bewildering is the settings of the game, which don't have a proper resolution selection and instead have a choice between 720, 1080 or "Desktop". And no less strange is the fact that there are few items in the game that seem to be not saved on the checkpoint, unlike pretty much every other action you do in the game. I haven't seen anything game breaking or soft locking the progress, but perhaps I was just lucky.

Overall, Yoku’s Island Express is novel, cute and mostly fun to explore, but lacks the ingenuity of Toki Tori 2, the sense of adventure like Treasure Adventure World or really deep stories like Knytt Underground. It's just a pinball metroidvania that's worth checking out, but don't expect to fall in love with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996501124', 'num_games_owned': 7813, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1530719923}
review:
The pinball adventure is a small but enticing category of games. Every time something like Mario Pinball Land or Rollers of the Realm comes out, I want to like it. I give myself over and wait to be impressed. Without fail, the results always disappoint me. In fact, I’ve been at it so long that I thought the worst. Crafting an expansive journey out of bumpers and flippers was perhaps just an impossible dream. However, if you pay attention to gaming long enough, you learn that nothing is beyond reach. Every idea, no matter how crazy, has its time and place. 2018 is the time and now is the place, because Yoku’s Island Express has hit the jackpot.

Want to know more? My expanded thoughts on the game can be found in my full review, which is published over on [url=https://techraptor.net/content/yoku-island-express-review] TechRaptor [/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022041814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 5295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1647209013}
review:
I won this during the Salien event in 2018.  I am very glad I did because I would have never bought or even searched for a game like this.  Truely a hidden gem among the mountain of mediocre games on Steam. At $19.99 I still think it is worth a purchase however I would feel more comfortable paying something like $15 or less.

Both my kids and I love it and gameplay is not too hard yet some of the secrets still make you think so as an adult I am not bored. Also the art work is pleasant to look at and the controls are so simple even a 5 year old can play this game effectively.  The story is good and instead of shooting your way past hordes of enemies like a Metroid series game you get to overcome obstacles with the flip of a paddle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198809160713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1530553945}
review:
《Yoku's Island Express》是一个开放的世界/ metroidvania-style弹球冒险,无缝地融合平台导航与弹球力学在开阔的世界。

优蜣螂集脚Mokumana岛的海滩上,准备新邮递员的职责。但古神岛被困在焦躁不安的睡眠和岛民饱受地震和风暴带来的噩梦。
　　优的冒险岛表达是一个独特的和古怪的手工制作的视觉效果,你会翱翔在空中,真空爆炸性的蜗牛,战斗Screetch,养活饥饿的狐猴,发现水果的神秘祭坛,后一个古老的神,希望帮助优重建小岛  邮政。

author: {'steamid': '76561197975523869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1531002132}

Pinball + Metroid.

The combination of distinct genres works very well.

review: Офигенная игра

author: {'steamid': '76561198061365207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1530396014}
review:
Ever wanted to be a dung beetle? How about a postman? Well you are in luck, because an exotic island has bestowed on you those roles. The catch? You are expected to save the island whilst dragging your ball around (I know what you are thinking, but you were only given one). Didn't know about it before you joined up? Too bad. Should have read the fine print buddy.

If this all sounds a bit outlandish, it is because the game is. What the developers of this game managed to do expertly, is too bring these concepts together in a way that kept me engaged for hours. They did this by: creating a picturesque environment; using unique game mechanics that works beautifully; adding a soundtrack that fits each part of the landscape of the island.

A creative 2D platformer that is worth your time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018460202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1530405163}
review: Fantastic and charming game.  Great blend of a metroidvania and pinball.  Pinball mechanics are fun and controls feel great.  A lot of varied environments and a lot of side missions and collectibles to do as well besides the main mission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101233182', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1543064246}
review:
Have you ever thought about play a game where the main character is a ant? [b]Well now you can![/b]

Yoku's Island Express is a genuine breath of fresh air!!

[h1]Gameplay / Concept[/h1]

Combine two genres that normally I'm  not suuuuuper crazy about - Pinball and Metroidvania (with some exploration and even sometimes puzzles). 
This two genres are combine to create a world that is incredibly fun to explore with each area feeling like a unique spin on the concept.

There's a surprising wealth of characters and side quests to discover with a lot of hidden areas and collectibles.
All of this it's done with loads of charm and i´m sure that will keep you coming back for more 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I strongly recommend it to people who love physics-based platformers and metroidvanias in general.

Check more recommendations from Exile [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/8004642/] here! [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198320845064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1530069751}
review:
评分8.5/10
渣渣如我 将近九个小时才通关（没有全收集全成就）
又拖了几天才写评测（迟到
先感谢谜叔的直播让我知道这个游戏（虽然我没看全他的直播）
小时候就很爱玩弹珠类游戏 姥姥家的红白机卡带26in1就有2D弹珠 是童年回忆的一部分
不过把弹珠游戏的机制放到解谜游戏里面还是第一次遇到（孤陋寡闻了）
加分点：
1.十分流畅！我电脑配置十分渣渣居然如此丝滑 感动（爆哭）
2.音乐和画面都很合我口味 热带小岛风 心情不好的时候听一听游戏标题界面的音乐就能开心起来 好游戏不是受苦而是让人开心哇[spoiler]（重度抖M当我没说） [/spoiler]
3.弹珠游戏的元素感觉在这个游戏里面丝毫没有违和感 不会给人一种很唐突的感觉（我不太会表达但大致就是这个意思啦）
4.存档真的很！方！便！
减分点：
1.容易卡关 容易迷路 迷路是其次的 弹珠游戏有时候让人抓狂 掌握不好力度的时候就是打不到出口你能把我怎么样（略略略）
2.任务系统似乎有点乱（？）不太能分清哪个是主线哪个是支线的感觉
3.主线可以做得再长一点的 玩完主线感觉意犹未尽 我也不是全收集玩家 通关就不太想碰了
4.价格……略贵了一点（摸着良心和我的钱包）
给新人玩家的建议：
1.善用存档功能
2.游戏内解锁路线买道具需要的水果挺多的 但是水果不难收集 早点升级包裹比较好
3.和NPC买东西的时候可以多点几次 说不定还可以讨价还价优惠一点买到 我目前遇到过一位（滑稽）

如果你对弹珠游戏感兴趣 想玩些真正的轻松养老游戏 这款绝对是好选择
早买早享受 63买不了吃亏买不了上当（喂）

author: {'steamid': '76561198797491982', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1529999803}

author: {'steamid': '76561198796098989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1531714814}
review:
看着游戏不怎么火，特地来评价一下。
先说说怎么看到这游戏的吧，当时首页推荐，看着这游戏美术就心动了（个人挺喜欢这种美术风格的游戏），再加上这优美的音乐，于是加入了愿望单，趁着夏促就买了，虽然也没便宜什么。

再来说说游戏方面，大家竟然都喜欢拿这游戏和Ori做比较，那我也直接拿比较的东西说吧。
两者的美术都很棒，Yoku这边的更为明朗一些，Ori的色调就显得冷一些，毕竟一个是热带岛屿是黑暗森林。音乐方面都做的很棒，游戏场景与背景音乐，两者搭配都非常融洽。剧情方面，Yoku是一个瓢虫拯救陷入危机的岛屿。Ori是一个精灵拯救濒临毁灭的森林，两者的剧情虽然都很简单，但是又都很完整。当然，游戏性也有很大的相似，那就是，都很硬核！一个是怎么弹都弹不到你想要的位置，一个是怎么跳，都被各种刺扎。一个是无限弹球循环，一个是无限复活循环。

最后随便说说个人感觉，这游戏为什么不火吧，可能是因为它是个弹珠游戏。首先对弹珠感兴趣的人应该是不多的，多数人可能是冲着美术以及音乐来购买（Ori那边的影响），再加上价格的定位，普通感兴趣的人也许就会觉得价格偏高，打折的力度也不是很给力，所以导致游戏不怎么火吧。

Yoku一周目9小时通关，Ori一周目9小时通关，也许是看着太相似，心血来潮来写个评论，各位随便看看就好。

author: {'steamid': '76561197960277861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 2134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1703190917}
review:
This game ate my weekend. It's pretty, it sounds great, it has fun (and forgiving) pinball mechanics, it has puzzles, it has a fun story, it has metroid-like progression mechanics... It costs less than 20 dollars!

I think the closest game I've played that brought this much joy it would be Guacamelee or Steamworld Dig 2.  The devs also listen to their playerbase, and removed a 'spyware-like' add-on they had included in the game.

While I don't plan on replaying it any time soon (too many other games on my queue), this game would be an excellent contender for speed-runs as progression does not have to be linear. I used slug bombs to finish most of the game before returning to the main storyline to collect the last few abilities.

2022 review update:
STEAMDECK+RANDOMIZER MODE.
I mentioned speedrunning, right? Now there's a randomizer mode and it is AWESOME. I was stuck in a lecture for the past 3 days and I had a blast getting to know the game through the lens of a random seed on my Steamdeck. I had one crash to desktop but that was after hours of play--the game has frequent save spots so it was a non-issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024297872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1528642871}
review:
Pinball and Metroid does not sound like a happy union, the gaming equivalent of sausages and milky bars. It came as something of a surprise then that not only does Yoku’s Island Express work, but it feels like it was always meant to be. Mashups are hardly a new thing in gaming, especially in the indie scene but it’s rare to see such a perfectly formed fusion of gaming genetics - Yoku is a real Kristin Kreuk of a video game, minus the links to sex trafficking cults. Rather than the pinball being a twist on the metroidvania formula, it’s absolutely a core mechanic. Flippers and bouncers are the only way to actually get anywhere in YIE, as Yoku cannot jump. The game is split into a large, typical Metroid style overworld and more discrete pinball style “tables” that essentially act as the games dungeons and bosses.

You can really feel the passion poured into the project by Villa Gorilla from the moment the game is booted up – it looks and sounds wonderful, and while it’s not quite up to the standard of Ori or Rayman Legends, it’s a far cry from the low effort pixel art affairs clogging up steam. The polish extends to the game design. - progression through the game is appealingly non-linear, with large interconnected areas and fast travel opening up just as back tracking starts to get a bit unwieldy. While there aren’t a huge number of upgrades, the ones we’ve got are quirky and designed to complement the pinball (so there’s no missiles, high jump or speed booster here). YIE is a very gentle game – there’s no death or direct combat of any kind, with the punishment for falling in the gutter being a minor loss of fruit (this game’s currency). Failure is its own punishment in YIE, which works fine within the games mechanics. There’s some precision pinballing required which can be frustrating enough without a pointless health bar killing the flow as well.

This does lead into the game’s biggest flaw, which is collectables. In a metroidvania, all collectables should do something, even if only in theory. You will never realistically come anywhere close to running out of missiles in Super Metroid after a point, but those extra five from every upgrade still objectively increase your power. With no combat or death, there’s less of an obvious upgrade path in YIE as you’ll never need ammo, heath or weapons. As a result the bulk of the collectables in the game basically do nothing until you get all of them, and even then it’s only a minor change to the ending. I’m sure the developers could have given a reward for every ten of these found, even if those rewards were only cosmetic. Thankfully there are also full fledged sidequests to the game, which do lead to more tangible rewards such as upgrades to tools or your fruit wallet (even if fruit wallet sounds like a horrifying prison innuendo).

If you’re a fan of metroidvania, then you really owe it to yourself to check YIE out. I really hope this does the business it deserves, as this was obvious a project of passion for the team and that’s something in short supply in the games industry. I’d recommend it wholeheartedly, and I’m really interested to see where Villa Gorilla goes next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025851530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1528165048}
review: Tracking with red shell. Immediately uninstalled.
developer_response:
Hello wethrowpie.

In response to community concerns about the integration of Redshell in Yoku's Island Express.

Redshell.io is a third party SDK which allows us to track the effectiveness of our marketing.

We take privacy very seriously and we do not integrate "Spyware" into this game or any games on our label.

We apologise for raising anyone's concerns. More information on Redshell is here IO Gamers[redshell.io].

Given the response by the community, we have removed Redshell from the game.

We promise that our intentions were never anything sinister. In the meantime, anyone still with any concerns can opt out immediately here: IO optout[redshell.io].

Our apologies for any inconvenience this has caused.

Regards
Team17 Support

author: {'steamid': '76561197972273179', 'num_games_owned': 1136, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1529410358}
review:
This game is an absolute delight! I loved every minute of it. 

Pros:
+ True Metroidvania experience with clever gating
+ A slightly more open-world than most games in the genre
+ Lovely, chill soundtrack (I still listen to it outside of the game)
+ Solid pinball mechanics with interesting "tables" 
+ You can press 'enter' to toot a party horn at any time and throw confetti \o/
+ Guys, it's super cute. Like, really bloody cute and I love it so much.

Cons:
- A little short at 6 hours. However, I was at only 50% completion by the end. Lots to collect after!

Absolutely  worth buying at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081997912', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1530637385}
review: 弹珠玩法很有趣，喜欢玩弹珠类的是个不错的选择，价格嘛，我个人感觉算是有点贵了，打折入手的话会更佳

author: {'steamid': '76561198052656542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1534729429}
review:
I've only been playing for an hour and a half, but at a first impression, this is a fantastic game.  I love pinball, but at first the pinball mechanics can be a bit frustrating.  I already feel like I have a farily good grasp on it, so don't let it bother you.  There's SO much pinball platforming in this right from the start you will naturally get better very quickly which is already very satisfying.

The graphics are pefect.  I like the fact that there aren't a bunch of settings, they just tweaked it to work great and look fantastic on their settings.  No thought needed, it just runs right.  It feels like a Nintendo game on the PC, which isn't surprising because it's also a switch game.  It's good, and I am glad to give them my $20 for their excellent work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116508766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1560205811}
review: Desde que vi o trailer do jogo e que soube que seria um metroidvania mesclado com pinball fiquei empolgado e com vontade de jogar. Ele cumpre tudo que promete, sendo bem divertido, com áreas para explorar, retorno a áreas já visitadas com novos power-ups para alcançar ítens e muito, muito pinball. Não pense nele como um Sonic Spinball que deu certo. Yoku`s Island Express tem um brilho próprio e especial.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991428059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1534981718}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972506592', 'num_games_owned': 856, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1529271768}
review: Fantastic puzzle/pinball/platform game. Amazingly polished and balanced, I don't think I encountered a single bug. Puzzles are just the right level of challenging, I never felt frustrated, and the music is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042023224', 'num_games_owned': 1596, 'num_reviews': 1032, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1529241788}
review:
작은 섬의 우편을 책임지는 행복한 딱정벌레.

새롭게 섬에 들어와 우편 배달부로 취직한 딱정벌레 요쿠가 되어 넓은 섬을 분주히 돌아다니며 캐릭터들의 편지를 배달해나가는 게임이다. 스토리는 요쿠의 편지 배달을 통해 진행되며 서브 퀘스트 역시 대다수가 우편 배달이다. 즉 우편으로 시작해 우편으로 끝나는 게임이고 게임 내내 편지 배달과 심부름을 반복하는 게임이다. 그래도 메트로배니아 게임답게 여러 장소를 돌아다니게 되고 게임의 진행에 따라 다양한 스킬과 아이템을 획득해나가게 된다.

상당히 특이하게도 메트로배니아에 핀볼을 접목시킨 게임이다. 요쿠의 이동과 아이템 획득, 퀘스트 진행, 그리고 보스전까지 전부 핀볼을 통해 진행된다. 핀볼을 통해 게임 상의 화폐인 과일을 획득하고 이 과일을 통해 새로운 발판을 열어 새로운 이동 장소를 발견하는 식이다. 공을 튀기고 장치를 작동시켜 잭팟을 터뜨리고 앞으로 나아가는 뽕맛이 상당하다! 뿐만 아니라 중반부터는 요쿠의 공을 꾸밀 수도 있는데, 이 공의 장식을 통해 진행되는 퀘스트가 존재한다. 딱정벌레의 공을 통해 핀볼이라는 컨셉을 아주 잘 살려낸 것이다. 공을 튀기는 타이밍이 살짝 어렵긴 하지만 아주 적응 못 할 정도는 아니다.

수집거리가 정말 다양하게 준비되있는 게임이다. NPC가 주는 다양한 퀘스트(를 가장한 심부름, 부려먹기)와 퀘스트를 통해 얻을 수 있는 아이템, 고리버들 뿌리 수집과 숨겨진 엔딩의 존재, 각 핀볼마다 특정 장치를 작동시켜 해방시킬 수 있는 풍뎅이 등, 모을 건 상다리가 부러질 정도로 다양하게 준비되있다. 100% 달성을 선호하는 게이머들을 위해 이것저것 신경을 많이 쓴 흔적이 엿보인다. 즉, 뭔가 스스로 찾고 모아나가는 재미가 출중한 게임인 것이다.  

다만 워프 지점이 다소 제한되있어 수집을 위해 섬을 방방곡곡 돌아다니기엔 조금 불편한 감이 있고, 정작 메인스토리만 놓고 보면 3-4시간이면 끝날 정도로 꽤나 짧은 편이다. 특이하게도 서브는 알찬데 메인이 살짝 부실한 격이다. 게다가 핀볼의 특성 상, 공이 항상 원하는 대로 움직여주질 않다보니 조작에서 짜증이 날 여지가 다분하기도 하다. 이건 조작감이 구리다기보단 핀볼 자체의 특성 때문에 불가피한 거긴 하지만.

메트로배니아에 핀볼을 접목시킨 상당히 이색적인 게임이다. 컨텐츠도 충실하고 번역도 나름 잘 되있으니 남녀노소 누구나 가볍게 즐기기 참 좋은 게임이다.

P.S! 쇠DDong구리가 필터 처리 되서 본문에는 불가피하게 딱정벌레라고 적어둔다.

https://blog.naver.com/kitpage/221311534390

author: {'steamid': '76561198306850565', 'num_games_owned': 5041, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1670932754}
review:
感谢[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31716674/]17173萤火虫[/url]提供的游戏。

[h1]尤库的小岛速递——2D平台与弹球的完美结合[/h1]

[h1]【简介】[/h1]
Yoku是一只小蜣螂，被派往Mokumana岛负责邮政业务。可是当他到达小岛时，才发现原本期待的宁静生活已被“噬神者”打破。拯救小岛的唯一方法是找到三个派系的长老，将他们聚集在一起举行治疗仪式。并沿途为岛上居民邮递信件。

Yoku通过短绳和一只球连在一起，二者密不可分（正符合他蜣螂的身份^ ^）。在平地上，是Yoku推着球走；而在面对更加复杂的地形时，就轮到他的小球派上用场了，依靠弹板将球弹起，小球就能带动Yoku到他想去的地方了。

[h1]【游戏特色】[/h1]
郁郁葱葱的热带丛林，银装素裹的皑皑雪山，飞流直下的瀑布，以及隐藏在洞穴里的神殿。游戏不仅包含多种独具特色的地形，美工方面也十分出色。细腻生动的手绘动画，动态效果，丰富的配色，再加上可爱的小动物形象，绝对是一场不容错过的视觉盛宴。

游戏的地图设计精巧，将平台部分和弹球环节巧妙结合。也许你正在平地上行走，一些通道会出现在恰到好处的地方，引导你顺利进入弹球区域。抓准时机按动弹板，尤库将通过完美衔接的滑道，一段爽快的轨迹！完成一个小区域后再进入下一区域，平台与弹球之间的不断转换是如此自然，形成了一个节奏顺畅的循环，吸引你不断探索。

Mokumana岛非常大，而且是无缝衔接的。如果把地图被分为若干个小区域，那么当你完成其中一个区域后，这里就与附近完全连通，你可以自由往返之前的地方。正应了非线性流程+开放式地图的特点。缩小地图可以看到整个岛屿被雾气所覆盖，随着Yoku探索每个角落和裂缝，岛屿的全貌也将随之揭晓。你也许会疑惑“那里该怎么去？”，而当你最终到达神秘地点，除了探索欲得到满足以外，还会有意想不到的发现。，

与许多平台游戏类似，Mokumana岛上充斥着各式各样的收集品，其中最常见的就是水果。水果既是分数，也可作为货币，解锁弹板进入新的区域，购买升级道具，开启快速旅行的通道。
[list]
    [*] 关于解锁弹板，我的理解是它减缓了早期的游戏进程。因为水果的供应是无限的，但是前期可能会因为水果不足而无法进入一些区域，但毫无疑问，这些区域即使在水果充足的游戏后期仍然会给你的探索带来新意。
    [*]升级道具里有的可以增加水果的容量，也有将 “柳条”，宝箱等收集要素在地图上标记出来的道具，对全收集党很有帮助。
    [*]四条覆盖全图的“蜂道（Beeline）”简直像是架在天上的高铁，每条蜂道上都有几个固定的站点，通过不断弹射来到达目的地，实现快速旅行。（弹射的过程挺有趣的）
[/list]
游戏的死亡惩罚很小，除了3-4个水果外不会有任何损失。弹球环节的底部设有一个弹板，掉下去了再弹上来就是，根本不需要从头开始，非常轻松愉快的一款游戏。大量分布的存档点也能让玩家随时保存进度。（游戏的存档点是花，完美融入环境。从未用过的存档点是花苞状，使用过一次后就变为盛开状，一个小细节。）

除了主线剧情外，游戏还提供了大量的游戏后内容。神秘的过场动画暗示了Mokumana岛内还存在着更加强大的力量（隐藏结局）。支线任务也很有趣，比如主角要攀登一座很高的雪山，于是收集了豆荚，温泉和肥料，种子快速生长成了一株巨型藤蔓！（杰克与魔豆的童话故事，而且藤蔓真的很高大啊）精心设计的挑战和丰富的隐藏地点等你发现。可升级技能使探索更加方便。

[h1]【总结】[/h1]
《尤库的小岛速递》是一场轻松愉快的冒险。游戏巧妙地将2D平台与弹球机制完美融合，二者间的不断转换十分自然，节奏顺畅。无缝衔接的开放式地图+非线性流程，不仅能让你一览小岛如诗如画的风光，还能在轻快的音乐中自由探索其中的秘密。有趣的任务，风趣的对话，可升级的技能，丰富的收集要素，隐藏结局等大量 post-game content 更进一步地充实了游戏内容。

author: {'steamid': '76561198018604282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1558070129}
review: I never expected to write a review for a pinball Metroidvania style game, but here you go.  This game is amazing.  The vizuals and style are adorable.  And the audio, from the sounds to the music, are amazing.  And it's just a helluva a lot of fun!  There are a few occasions where it was hard to make the ball go where you want it and it gets a little frustrating, but it also causes you to get better, and by the end there is little frustration.  I will say that there were times where I was just overwhelmed.  The map is so big and there is so much you CAN do (outside of the main story), that it can just be a little exhausting.  I did finish the game as of this writing, but I still plan on going back and trying to get all the things.  :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997152026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1528797593}
review:
- 8/10 - не для всех! :-\

- это один сплошной праздник качественного малобюджетного креатива в плане реализации игровой идеи, которая не могла, вроде как, в неидеальном мире существовать в принципе - но вот же она!! - работает как часы - на корпус стола от пинбола тут натянули не просто очередной тематический "скин", но целый жанр "метроидвания", посвященный жутковато-милой истории жука-навозника, устроившегося работать почтальоном - ну реальное же безумие - предельно уместное в том месте и в тот момент, когда чистейшей воды аркада переизобретает себя, ради красочно анимированного и прорисованного путешествия в недра популярного на независимой игровой сцене жанра! =))

author: {'steamid': '76561198259440756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1543053795}
review:
An completely adorable and unique game, unlike anything I've played in a long time. The pinball aspect brought me back to when I was a kid and Windows Pinball was the only game I could play. I enjoyed this game immensely. The music, the varied locations, the Metroidvania exploration style and of course the interesting characters and quests.

It is a short game, I finished it at 90% within 10 hours, but those were fantastic 10 hours.

In the end the backtracking is a little annoying, but the only real complaint I have for this game is, that there isn't more of it.

review:
Hallo Leser,

Yoku's Island Express macht in meinen Augen alles richitg, das Spiel fühlt sich flüssig an und bewundert mit den Features
die das Spiel zu bieten hat! ob Groß oder Klein hier findet jeder sein Spaß, was ich jedoch zu bemängeln habe, das Spiel Unterstützt kein Ps4 Controller also sich entweder ein Tool herunter Laden oder auf den Xbox Controller umsteigen.
Ich hatte auch Probleme mit meinem Monitor da das Spiel Maximal bei 60 Hz ausgelegt ist, nichtsdestotrotz ein Wunderbares Spiel! Kaufempfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025137607', 'num_games_owned': 714, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1528560238}
review:
After many years playing Metroid and Castlevania games, I was bored of Metroidvanias. 

I never liked Pinball games.

Yet, I loved Yoku's Island Express. 

It's a charming exploration adventure with many strange characters to help, the island is full of secrets that often require a bit of "thinking outside the box" to resolve. You move around the island with your dung-beetle and sometimes you'll have to resolve some "pinball boards" to move forward. These could became hardcore near the end but never too hard to complete in my opinion, you just need to pay attention at where the ball is before hitting it.

There's also a button dedicated to play your little trumpet and make "PHUEEEEEEEEE!" every time you want.

One of the most fun I had with games in the last few months, super recommended if you like funny adventures with original ideas and weird characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334368946', 'num_games_owned': 767, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1674464048}
review:
[h1]LuGN:8/10，作者不理人扣8分。[/h1]
意见提了三年作者鸟都没鸟我一下，也不知道后续更新改了没有。14块钱绝对是物有所值了，不太希望这游戏被埋没总之就凭回忆编点内容吧。

超级休闲的三维弹球作品，剧情主要是快递员跑遍小岛送信，地图分布稍微有一点点类银恶的味道。虽然有些啰嗦但支线任务都挺有意思的，找一个大空闲的时候玩应该会有比较好的体验。

author: {'steamid': '76561198092669392', 'num_games_owned': 3585, 'num_reviews': 345, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1694657553}
review:
[h1] Yoku’s Island Express – самый маленький почтальон в истории метроидваний [/h1]

Yoku’s Island Express была разработана шведами из Villa Gorilla. К релизу разработчикам помогали Team17 Digital, выступая как издатель. Игра вышла 29 мая 2018 года и получила от критиков очень положительные отзывы. Рассмотрим же, что нам предоставят ребята из Villa Gorilla.

[list]

[*] Наш маленький жучок Йоку со своим верным другом на верёвочке – камнем, прибывают на остров, чтобы занять рабочее место почтмейстера. Нас встретит Почтодактиль и отдаст нам свой значок «Почтмейстера». После этого у Йоку будет десятки новых знакомств, десятки новых врагов и множество нового. 

Игра из себя представляет метроидванию с интеграцией пинбола в игровой процесс. А это значит что встреча с «игровыми столами» неизбежна. Играть мы будем за маленького жучка Йоку, который без Камешка на верёвке никуда не ходит. Нашей целью будет разноска почты по всему острову, но основной задачей будет спасение Мокумы – сердца острова от странных существ. Для этого нужно принести газетку всем трём владыкам острова. 

Наш главный герой не умеет ничего кроме как катать шар со стороны в сторону и дудить в дудку-язычок. Разработчики обделили его другими возможностями, лишив даже прыжка. Но это не проблема, так как по всему острову раскиданы пинбольные платформы, которыми мы будем управлять с помощью RT и LT(R2, L2). Они как будут встречаться в мире для перемещения, так и в игровых столах пинбола. Впрочем, все головоломки и бои с врагами сменились игрой в пинбол, что достаточно необычно выглядит на бумаге, но очень приятно играется в жизни. Впрочем, вся игра сделана настолько хорошо, что игра в неё приносит лишь удовольствие и оставляет лишь приятные впечатления. 

Думаю, все знакомы с игрой в пинбол, а если уж вы не знаете что это такое, то вам стоит ознакомиться поближе с игровыми автоматами(не те которые в казино, а те которые были давным-давно, ещё до введения 3D в игры). У нас есть шар и есть зоны, через которые он должен пройти, дабы набрать очки. Ударять мяч мы будем двумя флипперами и главной целью в игре является набирание очков и не пропустить мяч в «ворота», которые находятся сразу за этими двумя флипперами. Впрочем, как испоганить пинбол – неизвестно и разработчики тоже этого не знают, поэтому сделали его очень отзывчивым и приятным. 

Вторая особенность игры – её нелинейность. Получив квесты вы можете выполнять их в любом порядке, не зависимо от этого вы будете прогрессировать и прокачивать своего жука. Ещё хочется сказать о куче секретов, которые спрятаны абсолютно на всём острове и поэтому какой-нибудь тупик окажется секреткой с корнем, который можно потом потратить в специальных тотемах. 

Местной валютой здесь выступают фрукты. За них мы будем покупать абсолютно всё, даже платформы для того, чтобы добраться в новую локацию, а поэтому спидраннерам эта игра, скорее всего, не по зубам. Получать же мы их будем, разбивая бампы и проходя через те вышеупомянутые зоны. Терять мы их будем при попадании в колючки, которые расположены в дрейне, месте под флипперами. Достаточно оригинальный подход к местной валюте, раньше я, лично, такого не видел. 

Ещё радует внимание к мелочам, так как ударив мяч несколько в другом месте флиппера – мяч полетит в секретку и мы получим незабываемые ощущения. Или же возможность покрасить свой шар в другой цвет, используя краски найденные в секретках. Игра даёт игроку огромный мир где можно заняться чем захочешь. Переигровка столов? Пожалуйста. Поиск секреток? Держи! Всё делалось для того, чтобы хотелось возвращаться в этот мир и знаете, у разработчиков это замечательно получилось. Поиграв лишь час вы сможете заметить сколько сил и любви вложили разработчики в свой «Островной Экспресс Йоку». 

[*] Пока играл в Yoku’s Island Express и смотрел на визуальный стиль всегда испытывал чувство дежавю, всё время не мог вспомнить где я это видел. И во время написания этого обзора вспомнил недавние игры серии Rayman и знаете, это таки одинаковые картинки. Rayman Legends и Rayman Origins смотрелись великолепно и Yoku’s Island Express – не исключение. Мир живой, сказочный. Эти тропики смотрятся настолько реально и живо, что иногда думаешь что может действительно где-то есть остров, где почту разносят жуки, главными бандитами являются антропоморфные слизни с банды Черепа, странные существа, от которых веет добром. 

[/list]

Вердикт:[i] «Островной Экспресс Йоку» на выходе получился лучше, чем его ожидали увидеть. Идеальное исполнение легендарного пинбола в инди-игре – что-то новенькое, но разработчики рискнули и не прогадали. Игра получилась на удивление шедевральной и её можно только хвалить. Игра к тому же не тяжелая, даже казуальная, а поэтому подойдёт для всех возрастов и полов. Жаль приключение Йоку длиться лишь шесть часов, это очень мало для такого огромного мира. Это единственное за что можно поругать Yoku’s Island Express, а всё остальное на высшем уровне. [/i]

Оценка:[b] 9.7/10.[/b] Пинбол и жуки с мячами на верёвках ещё никогда так хорошо не смотрелись вместе.

Обзор был составлен Ci8, главным куратором в [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/bigbadwhl] BigBadWhale Games[/url], куратором в [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Obzzor4ik]«Обзоры онлайн»[/url] в сотрудничестве с [url=http://welovebundles.ru/]BELONGPLAY[/url] 

Ключ к игре предоставил издатель, но это [u]никак не влияет[/u] на моё мнение и оценку.

Оценка редакции:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1276824468

"Лучшее окружение" по версии КОКИ в 2018 году.

review: 72 hours played at time of review. This game is a cross between pinball and Fancy Pants Adventures. Fun to pick up and play. Not a very in depth story line but that doesnt matter. The sound effects and visuals keep you engaged and on the easy setting it is almost impossible to die allowing you to focus on the puzzles. Great family game, great for kids and adults and also a good "pass the controller" game. Its not an AAA title and doesn't try to be. Well worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990816800', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1528478153}
review:
What would happen if you combined Metroid with pinball?  It’s a strange question to say the least, and Yoku’s Island Express is probably the best answer we’ll ever get.

Like Metroid before it, Yoku's Island (not to be confused with Yoshi's Island) features a large, interconnected world full of obstacles that can only be overcome with certain abilities.  What really sets it apart, however, is the fact that you can't jump.  Instead, you must use pinball flippers to go airborne and traverse the environment.

Although this might sound gimmicky and even tedious, rest assured, Yoku's blend of pinball and exploration is fantastic.  The world is designed such that basic navigation is painless and typically consists of rolling around and occasionally activating flippers (some of which require fruit to unlock) to reach higher ground.  It's only when you near important items and/or locations that Yoku goes into full-fledged pinball mode with level layouts that resemble pinball tables and thorns at the bottom of the screen that take away some of your fruit if you happen to fall into them.

Most of Yoku’s gameplay revolves around tackling quests given to you by the island’s many zany inhabitants.  Each quest is handily marked on a map that you can pull up at any time, and as large as the island is, trust me when I say that you’ll need it.  These range from fetch quests to boss battles, and the best part is that they can be completed in almost any order.  There are also loads of collectibles, including hard-to-find treasure chests and plant-like creatures called “Wickerlings.”  As a result, there’s almost always something to do even outside of quests and exploration usually yields great rewards.

Yoku’s Island is also brimming with charm.  Its colorful, Rayman-like visuals and upbeat music go a long ways towards making it a real joy to play, and the game’s wacky characters, all of whom grunt and babble Banjo Kazooie-style, are downright adorable.  If I ever were to need to recommend a “feel-good” game to someone, this would make the top of the list.

The only complaints I have are that the game is a bit [i]too[/i] forgiving and the island itself can sometimes be a chore to navigate.  It isn’t possible to die–only to lose fruit–and fruit is so readily available that it never feels like a loss even when it’s taken from you.  Getting from place to place isn’t always easy even with the aid of the map, either, and the quasi-fast travel system in the form of the “Beeline” (which functions almost like a mid-air tram system) does little to help matters since it covers a limited area and isn’t available until later in the game.

If there’s one thing I can say about Yoku’s Island Express, it’s that it’s a grand achievement.  Not only is it the freshest “Metroidvania” I’ve played to date, but it also proves that platformers and pinball games [i]can[/i] be mashed together with stellar results.  I’ll admit that I was skeptical going into it, but I ended up having to tear myself away from the computer each and every time I sat down to play it.  If you’re going to pick up one indie sidescroller this year, make it this one.  I promise you won’t regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080035468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1528315024}
review:
Wow, just wow. When I bought this game and I didnt expect it to be this awesome.
The graphic is gorgeous, character designs are very lovely. The gameplay is very creative, fun and casual.

Personally, one of the thing that I like the most about this game is the soundtrack.
I LOVE IT. Relaxing and catchy!!

I really hope they will make the sequel, because I would love to play as Yoku the postmaster beetle again :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018590778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1608387092}
review:
What a delightful little game. The seemingly nutty idea of mixing pinball and metroidvania works surprisingly well. And the overall design of the game matches in terms of nuttiness. It's all so charming. Characters in the game will e.g. dive by lettings themselves get partly swallowed by fish and then the fish pulls them under water. Or climb by having animals bite plants and then swing around them - it's best to watch a video if you can't imagine this. And I still remember the very first couple of minutes gameplay when the logo of the game appears - I for one had to chuckle at the way that was presented.

But not only does it ooze charm but it also handles very well. Pinball mechanics may not be particularly realistic but hey... you're playing with a beetle strapped to a ball. The important point is that it feels alright. And traversing the (huge!) map works a lot faster than one would initially expect because of all sorts of shortcuts and additional methods of transportation one eventually unlocks. Somewhere I read a comment that it can be annoying to go upwards since obviously the ball only falls down. But there are all sorts of flippers and lanes that fling/move you upwards, so I've never found this to be an issue.

Oh and the map might just be one of the best I've ever seen - it simply zooms out the game so that you can see the whole world (although some things don't seem to update properly at times - a bit buggy). but you can also zoom in and pan around.

The only flaw I've found is that it does feel very much like a children's game in that it's very easy. I've played quite a bit of Pinball FX and Pro Pinball and there hasn't really been any challenge. So I'm really just exploring and having fun discovering all those different biomes and new characters and quests. Of which there are many. It's like every couple of minutes that you come across some NPC to chat with. Still - most of the time, I run around with maxed out fruits and I wonder whether they couldn't have included some aspect where if you play well (which reminds me - there is no combo system, no time limits and all shots are easy to pull off), you get something - once fruit is maxed out, symbols change to something else and do... whatever. Or something.

And since I know that length matters to people with limited finances - it took me about 7 hours to finish regularly (although I did many side quests and whatnot) and after about 10 hours, I'm at 97% and saw the "true ending". Now to find the remaining 3...

author: {'steamid': '76561197971485856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1529427793}
review:
Not even done with it, but I can safely call this a hidden gem. If you've somehow found your way to this game's store page, you have the chance to play a real treat. Combining pinball with metroidvania (let that simmer in your mind for a minute), Yoku's Island Express is a fresh take on a solid genre. 

PROS:
- Addictive gameplay
- Great flow
- Secrets to find
- Beautiful artwork
- Relaxing

CONS:
- I honestly can't think of any.

NEUTRALS:
- Save points galore
- No deaths (You just lose a bit of fruit)
- Length is supposedly around 6 hours

A sleeper hit for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992886766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1528160965}
review:
A metroidvania and...PINBALL!? Yes, as strange as it sounds that is the gist of Yoku's Island Express. And it's totally awsome.

Super charming little game with great graphics, gameplay, music and satisfying progression. From snow covered mountains to dank caverns deep underground, the world has plenty to explore and see. Tons of secret areas and collectibles help to add even more spice (don't worry, all collectibles can be revealed on map via certains items). True to metroidvania fashion, you'll find items and upgrades that'll let you get to areas you couldn't before.

The pinball mechanics work surprisingly well and make getting around the world quite an unique experience. Sure, there are some tricky shots that will need to be made but once you get the hang of it you shouldn't remain stuck at any one area for overlong. Exploring the world itself via nifty pinball movement and solving puzzles is the challenge, as there is no way to get a Game Over.

9/10! A unique and charming metroidvania with pinball mechanics!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963015762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1705625517}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030162114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1529688792}
review:
Such a feelgood game!! It´s cute, beautiful and relaxing -and a lot of fun pinball action. 
And it´s super clean. Very few controls to keep track on,  you dont have to think about saving and the menu is simple.
The game loads in no time and runs smoothly. No problems at all technically. But simplicity ends there. The map for example is awsome, and the care for detail in drawings. Also how much there is to do. I have "finished" it now but there are many hours left of exploring  :)
 
I love how the characters look and speak -made me giggle everytime. And how there´s a new surprise around every corner and you can go wherever you want. Sometimes you need to do something first to be able to move on though. Might get confusing for a moment, but that´s the price you have to pay to be able to move around freely and not being locked into a linear questline i think.
 
I did have to work some on my pinball skills, and start to look at whats happening instead of just hammering away haha, but if I can do it anyone can. It doesnt take a pinball wizard, just a little patience sometimes, especially when you need to both walk sideways and flip the ball using a keyboard.   

The only con I can think of would maybe be the music in some areas. It could even be a bit more "themed"  through out the game. The soundeffects are hilarious tho!

author: {'steamid': '76561198331503333', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1529304302}
review:
[h1]《尤库的小岛速递》——小瓢虫快递员版三维弹球[/h1]

作为一款由Villa Gorilla开发的横版独立冒险弹球游戏，游戏的美术画风清新明朗（偏奥日风），背景音乐轻快舒心，与画面效果相得益彰，较为立体地刻画了热带南方小岛Mokumana 。此外，《尤库的小岛速递》于5月30日获得了IGN评分8.0的良好成绩。


本作融合了弹珠机制、平台跳跃以及开放世界等要素，但整个游戏非线性，玩家可以自由选择多条任务线，操控着小瓢虫YOKU推动弹球移动，并在移动过程中借由蓝色和黄色挡板对弹球进行击打以改变弹球的运动轨迹、进入下一场景。

除了用L shift和R shift控制挡板外，游戏还加入了许多场景互动和能力道具——噪音制造器、望远镜、罐子、喷壶、风车、宝箱，并通过收集热带水果等消耗品来购买道具、升级钱包、解锁挡板和开通捷径进入场景。其中较为特殊的收集品是柳条，柳条作为激活Mokumana岛秘密的必要条件，必须全收集才能解开小岛的秘密。

游戏的地图做得非常精细：村庄、矿井、雪域、图腾塔、骨髓山、子弹花园......在不同的地图场景中有不同的任务衔接，在收集消耗品的同时不会让玩家感到过于枯燥。而且，场景中挡板的位置也是设计得非常巧妙，融入机关等要素后也不会刁钻得让玩家卡关。

本作的交互任务也是一大亮点：树蛇（拿到蘑菇）、小兔子（清理灰虫子）、土著居民（拜访子弹园丁）、猫头鹰（购买藏宝图）、太空教士（去往引擎室）、BOSS（击退蜘蛛精）、长老（查清弑神者伪装）、NIM（开始仪式）......特别是遇到兔子商人升级钱包然而can't afford it的时候，这时兔子SKEEPER会极具人情味的跟你说“哦，还不够吗？不要担心，我知道没钱的感觉”，随后将你的钱包升级。而等到玩家收集到足够的钱之后去给她时，她会对你说“谢谢，我早知道你是个诚实的人”并给玩家额外的奖励。

关于游戏的剧情，表面上是主人公小瓢虫YOKU来到Mokumana 岛接替邮递员送包裹、重建邮局，其实随着故事的展开，你会发现这仅仅只是冰山一角.........

推荐爱好弹珠类游戏的朋友尝尝鲜~


8.0/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197961143961', 'num_games_owned': 3030, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1668553496}
review:
An hour into this and I already know this is the most satisfactory $20 of fun I've spent on a chill-out game all year. There's a YT video that's about 4 hours long that shows the full game - although they didn't hunt all the secrets.  I can see being 100% completionist taking a good while.  There's some back-tracking required, so if you think you're stuck on a puzzle go re-explore where you've been.  I don't think this is the sort of game you'd want to speed run anyway.  But that gives you an approximation of how much is here once you know your way through it.  

This game is just magic.  Highly recommended.  It's like pinball therapy.

review: It sounds odd, pinball/metroid-vania, but in this package it works.  The pinball elements are well integrated into the game and play very well, and there are plenty of clever surprises throughout.  It kind of feels like throwing Steamworld Dig 2, Ori and a pinball machine in a blender created this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113497432', 'num_games_owned': 5894, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1563826115}
review:
[h1] [b] Good lord, that's not a pinball he is carrying around	[/b]	[/h1]
Yoku's Island Express is an adorable Open world exploration game with an interesting restriction to movement.
Thinking back on Yoshis island, because, idk, for whatever reason that was the first thing that came to mind when playing this, there was a limitation for having both characters, in that Baby Mario brings nothing to the game, its solely an object you must carry around.
In this, its an interesting restriction, like 2 different genres cooperating to reach a location that you couldnt with your character alone. The limited platforming and skills of the beetle are met with the ball he carries around, introducing the pinball aspect.

[h1] Metroidvania or Metroid-like[/h1]
One rather specific genre, that often goes misused. 
In fact it does offer an open map to explore, with locations you will cross many times. Every time you learn a new skill that opens passage to a new area, or that helps figure out how to reach a certain item, or how to find certain hidden collectibles, or even help finishing side quest.
However, the Castlevanias everyone thinks of, or simply the ones i have played, have RNG/RPG elements to them, character status, RNG item drops, weapon and armor stats. Those are things this game isn't at all about.

[h1] Story	[/h1]
Yoku, the island´s new Postman, arrives expecting a relaxed job on this beautiful tropical Forrest, but as he is getting acquainted with the area and its inhabitants through small errands, a deeper, darker story involving ancient Gods unsolves.
I mostly glanced at the story, which is typical coming from me, but more to the fact that it was about the presentation and not so much the story. This charming and colorful world and its oddball inhabitants, that's what held my interest.

[h1] Gameplay	[/h1]
Its open for exploration, but there's a clear main objective right from the moment the player enters the island. Expectedly, its left to the player to find the route. But its just enough so he doesn't feel lost.
It can be confusing to complete a certain  side quest, or to find passage to another area, but it opens up just by following the main line, learning new skills, new items, and how to apply them in previously blocked/unreachable areas.
throughout the map there are hidden collectibles and fruit to find and collect.
With fruit working as currency and used to unlock springs.

[b] Controls:	[/b]
Dung Beetle: Is controlled by the player, attached to the ball, always rolls it around, used to interact with the environment. Later through skills can access to new areas, otherwise it mostly just walks left and right.
Ball: is used through bumpers and flippers with the use of the shoulder buttons, in more Pinball oriented sections, with the beetle getting dragged behind. 
Pinball sections often  require specific aiming, to grab items or exit the level, but nowhere near frustrating.
[b]World:	[/b]
The world is a giant Pinball machine.
There is a mix of exploration and closed space Pinball sections. Its when moving vertically that it really shows how much of the map is done with the ball.
Its beautiful and striking when revealing how much of the map is made for the use of flippers, its through great level design that both genres blend without destroying the island setting.
As the cute dung beetle, the player can only move left and right, using the learned skills along the way to open and reach new areas, talk to other characters, collect items, take side quests.
To go just about anywhere on this island, it will only be done with the ball, through various bumpers and flippers.

[h1] Final Thoughts	[/h1]
Its a charming and well made hybrid that manages some great level design even with most of the map being made out of small pinball tables
There's one obvious fault with the concept. It being a, for the most part, pinball game, to move around, its impossible not to revisit many of the same table areas. And even then, i think their solution, with traveling points, is well placed enough that you can quickly travel without much hassle.

[h1]__The One glitch__[/h1]
The first thing i did was explore as much of the map as i could, ignoring the main line. But i still decided to collect every item and side quest i found. I really wouldn't recommend doing that until its fixed.
Because what happened to me was, that one of the characters didn't spawn, he would construct the only way to reach the higher areas early on, and without him i had to start the game all over again.

[i] FINAL SCORE: 8/10	[/i]

[quote] This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/gaming_until_end]Gaming Until End[/url], through the generous contribution of [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/HellCowON]HellCow.[/url] [/quote]
